cards.back: O (upper bound), Ω (lower bound), Θ (tight), Õ (ignore logs), Op (probabilistic), o (strictly smaller), ω (strictly larger). Plus ~ (asymptotic equivalence).
f(n) = Ω(g(n)) if ∃ C > 0, n₀ such that |f(n)| ≥ C|g(n)| for all n ≥ n₀. It's the lower bound: 'f grows at least as fast as g'.
f(n) = Θ(g(n)) iff f = O(g) AND f = Ω(g). Equivalent to: ∃ C₁, C₂ > 0 such that C₁|g| ≤ |f| ≤ C₂|g| for large n. 'Exact order.'
O: |f/g| ≤ C (bounded ratio). o: |f/g| → 0 (ratio vanishes). Little-o is strictly stronger — f = o(g) implies f = O(g) but not vice versa.
f ~ g means lim |f/g| = 1. The strongest statement — f and g become proportionally identical. Example: n² + n ~ n² because (n² + n)/n² → 1.

cards.front: Give the classic Ω(n log n) example.
cards.back: Comparison-based sorting requires Ω(n log n) comparisons — information-theoretic lower bound from log₂(n!). No algorithm can beat it. Merge sort achieves this, so it's optimal.
Õ(g(n)) means O(g(n)·logℓ(n)) for some ℓ. Ignores logarithmic factors. Used when logs are practically insignificant.

cards.front: Why does Monte Carlo use Op instead of O?
cards.back: Monte Carlo produces random estimates, so the error is a random variable. Op(1/√n) means the error is stochastically bounded by 1/√n — bounded with high probability, not deterministically.
Strongest to weakest: f ~ g → f = Θ(g) → f = O(g) or f = Ω(g) → f = o(g) or f = ω(g). Note: o and ω are strict (no equality allowed).
Both! O(n²): |3n²+5n+2| ≤ 10n² for n ≥ 1. Ω(n²): |3n²+5n+2| ≥ 3n². Combined: Θ(n²). Also O(n³) but that's weaker.
